2.html: npm i kaplanck
2.title: Installation

3.html:
The following assumes you already have a KaPlay project set up.

Lets create our own version of "Hello World" using KaPlanck.

Lets start by importing our dependencies and add a KaPlay instance:

// 1. Import modules.
import KaPlanckPlugin from "kaplanck";
import kaplay from "kaplay";
import { Vec2 } from "planck";
 
// 2. Create a new KaPlay instance.
const k = kaplay({
  global: false,
  plugins: [KaPlanckPlugin()], 
});

As shown, adding the plugin to KaPlay is as easy as adding the highlighted line.

Next, let us add a world container (a game object that holds our physics world):

// 1. Import modules.
import KaPlanckPlugin from "kaplanck";
import kaplay from "kaplay";
import { Vec2 } from "planck";
 
// 2. Create a new KaPlay instance.
const k = kaplay({
  global: false,
  plugins: [KaPlanckPlugin()],
});
 
// 3. Add a world container with gravity set to x: 0 y: 10.
const worldContainer = k.add([ 
  k.kpWorld({ 
    gravity: new Vec2(0, 10), 
  }), 
]);

Note that Vec2 is from Planck and not from KaPlay.

Now that we have our world container set up, let's add a ground to it. We can do this by creating a static body with an edge shape:

// 1. Import modules.
import KaPlanckPlugin from "kaplanck";
import kaplay from "kaplay";
import { Vec2 } from "planck";
 
// 2. Create a new KaPlay instance.
const k = kaplay({
  global: false,
  plugins: [KaPlanckPlugin()],
});
 
// 3. Add a world container with gravity set to x: 0 y: 10.
const worldContainer = k.add([
  k.kpWorld({
    gravity: new Vec2(0, 10),
  }),
]);
 
// 4. Add ground by creating a static body with an edge shape.
worldContainer.add([ 
  k.kpPos(k.kpCenter()), 
  k.kpRotate(Math.PI * 0.1), 
  k.kpEdgeShape({ 
    v1: new Vec2(-10, 0), 
    v2: new Vec2(10, 0), 
    draw: true, 
  }), 
  k.kpBody({ 
    type: "static", 
  }), 
  k.kpFixture(), 
]);

Again, note that here we are using kpPos and kpRotate instead of pos and rotate.

Finally, let's add a simple ball to the world. We can do this by creating a dynamic body with a circle shape:

// 1. Import modules.
import KaPlanckPlugin from "kaplanck";
import kaplay from "kaplay";
import { Vec2 } from "planck";
 
// 2. Create a new KaPlay instance.
const k = kaplay({
  global: false,
  plugins: [KaPlanckPlugin()],
});
 
// 3. Add a world container with gravity set to x: 0 y: 10.
const worldContainer = k.add([
  k.kpWorld({
    gravity: new Vec2(0, 10),
  }),
]);
 
// 4. Add ground by creating a static body with an edge shape.
worldContainer.add([
  k.kpPos(k.kpCenter()),
  k.kpRotate(Math.PI * 0.1),
  k.kpEdgeShape({
    v1: new Vec2(-10, 0),
    v2: new Vec2(10, 0),
    draw: true,
  }),
  k.kpBody({
    type: "static",
  }),
  k.kpFixture(),
]);
 
// 5. Add a ball by creating a dynamic body with a circle shape.
worldContainer.add([ 
  k.kpPos(k.kpCenter().sub({ x: k.rand(-10, 10), y: k.rand(10, 15) })), 
  k.kpRotate(), 
  k.kpCircleShape({ 
    radius: 1, 
    draw: true, 
  }), 
  k.kpBody({ type: "dynamic" }), 
  k.kpFixture({ density: 1, friction: 0.3 }), 
  k.offscreen({ destroy: true }), 
]);

I know this is not the most complex example, but it demonstrates a basic setup using KaPlay and Planck for creating a physics-based games.

Well with that being said, hope this plugin helps you get started with building physics-based games or interactive applications!

If you have any questions or need further assistance, feel free to ask. Happy coding!
3.title: Example

5.title: Interfaces

8.html:
KaPlanckPlugin(opt?): (k) => KaPlanckPluginCtx

A plugin to allows to use PlanckJS seamlessly with KaPlay.

IMPORTANT

Vec2 from KaPlay and Vec2 from PlanckJS are different, please use them accordingly.

PlanckJS uses radians for angles while KaPlay uses degrees, please make use of KaPlay's tools to convert between them.
8.text:
KaPlanckPlugin(opt?): (k) => KaPlanckPluginCtx

A plugin to allows to use PlanckJS seamlessly with KaPlay.
IMPORTANT
Vec2 from KaPlay and Vec2 from PlanckJS are different, please use them accordingly.
PlanckJS uses radians for angles while KaPlay uses degrees, please make use of KaPlay's
tools to convert between them.
8.title: Function: KaPlanckPlugin()

348.html:
onKPCollide(tagA, tagB, action, worldContainer?): void

Register an event that runs once when 2 game objs with certain tags collides. Requires an object with the kpWorld component. Requires objects with kpFixture or kpFixtures components.
348.text:

Register an event that runs once when 2 game objs with certain tags collides.
Requires an object with the kpWorld component.
Requires objects with kpFixture or kpFixtures components.
